review.title: Fixing the Infix: Unsupervised Discovery of Root-and-Pattern Morphology
review.abstract: We present an unsupervised and language-agnostic method for learning root-and-pattern morphology in Semitic languages. This form of morphology, abundant in Semitic languages, has not been handled in prior unsupervised approaches. We harness the syntactico-semantic information in distributed word representations to solve the long standing problem of root-and-pattern discovery in Semitic languages. Moreover, we construct an unsupervised root extractor based on the learned rules. We prove the validity of learned rules across Arabic, Hebrew, and Amharic, alongside showing that our root extractor compares favorably with a widely used, carefully engineered root extractor: ISRI.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 2.02 211v 2 [cs.C L] February 11, 2017 Agnostic method for learning the morphology of roots and patterns in Semitic languages. We use syntactic-semantic information in distributed word representations to solve the long-standing problem of the discovery of roots and patterns in Semitic languages. Morphological rules of roots and patterns, which we learn unsupervised, are validated by native speakers in Arabic, Hebrew and Amharic. In addition, the rules are used to construct an unattended root extractor called JZR, which we compare to ISRI, a widely used and carefully developed root extractor for Arabic.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Morphological analysis is a core task in natural language processing and thus of central interest in computer-aided linguistics (Kurimo et al., 2010) with widespread application benefits (Korenius et al., 2004; Skorkovska ́, 2012; Seddah et al., 2010; Semmar et al., 2006; Larkey et al., 2002).Computational approach to morphological analysis for lemmatization and stemming trust on knowledge of the mapping from inflected forms to lemmas. However, the more widespread systems learning these arrangements are limited to dealing with conventional morphology, Learning overt affixes and their interactions with stems (Creutz and Lagus, 2005; Soricut et al, 2011; Goldsmith et al, 2000; Pasha et al, 2014; Buckwalter, 2004).

sections.heading: 2 Root-and-Pattern Morphology Illustration
sections.text: In Semitic languages, a pattern (bound morphem) is applied to a root (free morphem) to produce a word. Generally, the roots consist of 3 consonants; example: (to write, kataba, ktb) (Aljlayl and Frieder, 2002). Patterns encode the placement of the 3 consonants in relation to the letters added, one example being C1AC2iC3. Here, the vowel "A" is placed between the first and second consonants and the vowel "i" between the second and third consonants. In our example, this pattern is applied to the 3-consonant root, which is the resulting word (scribe, kAtib, ktb). This pattern encodes the agent "agent" and the agent "vertience."

sections.heading: 3 Learning of Morphological Rules
sections.text: Our proposed method is based on three models: an orthographic model for concatenated morphology and an orthographic model for root and pattern morphology signal all possible morphological (candidate) rules and all possible (candidate) pairs of morphologically related words from an orthographic perspective. Then a semantic model confirms whether a candidate rule is morphologically valid and whether a word pair is morphologically related. Existing approaches to root and pattern morphology in literature tend to be a set of orthographic rules defining the model; the heavy dependence on expert linguistic rules naturally leads to poor coverage. Moreover, the orthographic rules disregard the semantically motivated morphological transformation. For example, the word pair (based on these morthographic models) establishes a morthographic relationship between the available patterns and morthographic analysis.

sections.heading: 3.1 Orthographic Models
sections.text: In order to recognize morphological rules from an orthographic point of view, we define two models, one for concatenated morphology and one for root and pattern morphology.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Concatenative Morphology
sections.text: In concatenating morphology, affixes hang on a stem (Siegel, 1974), so we model concatenated morphology as the process of deleting from one end of the word followed by insertions at the same end. For example, the words (desk, maktab, mktb) and (desk, almaktab, lmktb) are considered morphologically from an orthographic point of view, with 0 deletions at the beginning of the word followed by two insertions (a, l), which would contribute to the candidate rule (prefix, φ, al), another example would be the word pair (desk, almaktab, lmktb) and (desk, wamaktab, wmktb), on the basis of this model they would be linked by two deletions (a, l) and two insertions (w, a), and this pair would contribute to the rule (prefix, al, wa).

sections.heading: 3.1.2 Root-and-Pattern Morphology
sections.text: All Semitic languages have in common the following two characteristics of the relations between roots and their pattern-related words at the orthographic level (Greenberg, 1950): • Roots are predominantly triliteral. • The root consonants (C1, C2, C3) retain their relative order after they have combined with a pattern to form a word. In Table 1, for example, the word kAtib would be compared with the tri-literal root cottage, and consequently the template C1AC2iC3 would be regarded as a root and pattern template.

sections.heading: 3.2 Semantic Model
sections.text: Not every word pair that obeys the orthographic properties is a morphologically related pair. To determine, for example, that a word pair that obeys the orthographic properties is actually morphologically related, we use the semantic relationship between the words via word representations. This is because word representations and their geometry encode syntactical-semantic relationships in vector space (Mikolov et al., 2013b). Consider, for example, the two pairs: (1) (written, kataba, ktb), (desk, maktab, mktb)) and (2) (played, la'iba, l'b) (playing field, ml'b). We can check that abmal is a word, maktab, mktb ', mktb) and (2) (played, la'iba, l'b), (playing field, ml'b), a similar pattern.

sections.heading: 3.3 Algorithmic Implementation
sections.text: Our approach is inspired by (Soricut and Och, 2015) which, limited to concatenated morphology, serves as the primary mechanism for generating the concatenated morphological rules for the languages in our study. Our contribution consists in adapting their approach to non-concatenative morphology. Our system is implemented in 4 steps: 1. generation of vocabulary rules in our system (1. generation of vocabulary rules), 2. generation of candidates (root, derived) pairsgrouped into sentences based on the underlying orthographic transformation. These sentences represent the morphological rules in our system. (2. generation of candidates), 3. generation of graphers using the semantic and orthographic model. (Validation of candidate rules).4. sections.heading: 5 Experiments and Results
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate our method in various ways in three different languages (Arabic, Hebrew, Amharic), first qualitatively evaluating our method by checking the root and pattern rules it discovers in the three languages, then quantitatively evaluating JDR by comparing its accuracy with the widely used Arabic ISRI root extractor (Taghva et al., 2005) on a sample of 1200 words.

sections.heading: 5.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: For each of the three languages, we use the readily available Polyglot1 word representations and vocabulary. These 64d word representations were created based on Wikipedia in the respective language. Arabic and Hebrew embeddings were limited to the top 100K words, while Amharic, as a resource-poor language, was limited to the top 10K words. sections.heading: 5.2 Evaluation of Root-and-Pattern rules
sections.text: We validate root-and-pattern rules in the three languages by evaluating the rules for scoring semprq and having a native speaker of each language rate the 30 best rules. All 30 rules in each of the three languages were considered correct, confirming the linguistic agnosticity and performance of our uncontrolled approach.

sections.heading: 5.3 Intrinsic Evaluation on Arabic
sections.text: In this experiment, we look at three Arabic root extractors: JZR, JZR (limited), and ISRI, and evaluate them using a sample of 1200 words. JZR (limited) is a version of JZR that is limited to concatenating morphology, whereas the comparison reflects the added value of the root and pattern rules discovered. Results (summarized in Table 2) show: (1) JZR compares favorably with ISRI, a carefully developed rules-based and language-specific root extractor (2) that limits JZR to concatenating morphology, reflecting the importance of the non-concatenating rules covered by JZR. We also maintain that this decline is an underestimation of the importance of the root and pattern rules learned. We discuss this claim in detail in Appendix A, along with further analysis of the results and sample results.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: This paper presents an unattended method for discovering the morphology of roots and patterns in Semitic languages. The discovered rules serve to extract Semitic roots, which are the basic units of these languages. Intrinsic and extrinsic evaluations of these rules allow us to validate both our pattern recognition method and our root extraction method (JDR), with performance not too far removed from a rules-based language-specific (in this case Arabic) root extractor.

sections.heading: A Discussion
sections.text: We believe that the drop in performance in limiting JDR to concatenated morphology underestimates the abundance of root and pattern morphology in Arabic. This is because the way we define concatenated morphology could capture the morphology of root and pattern patterns under strict conditions.
